content:
Notes # INI Student Handbook # Per semester, choose at least 36(academic) units, at most 48(academic) + 3(APD) + 12(non-academic) units. At most 24 units from undergrad and needs approval from INI. Per semester, choose at least 1 core course, unless you have done all of them. Introductory courses cannot be taken after the advanced ones. You can drop courses in 6 weeks from the beginning of the semester. You have one chance to use drop voucher every year, which prevents a withdrawal letter ‘W’ shown on the transcript. Waitlist is common. You will definitely get into the INI courses, and you probably have a strong chance with the SCS ones as well. Strategy # As I plan to take the renowned SCS systems courses alongside fulfilling the Cyber Defense Concentration track, I will start by listing all the relevant courses before brute-forcing possible combinations.
Cyber Defense Concentration # Minimal requirementsï¼š
14-513: Introduction to Computer Systems (Exempted from summer mini 15-503) Summer 6 units 20 hrs/week elective 14-642: Introduction to Embedded Systems Fall 12 units 20.1 hrs/week system core 14-735: Secure Coding Fall 12 units 11 hrs/week security core 14-740: Fundamentals of Telecommunications Networks Fall/Spring 12 units 12.4 hrs/week networking core 14-741: Introduction to Information Security Fall/Spring 12 units 15.1 hrs/week security core 14-742: Security in Networked Systems Spring 12 units 13.7 hrs/week AoC 14-761: Applied Information Assurance Fall/Spring 12 units 11.2 hrs/week elective 14-817: Cyber Risk Modeling Fall/Spring 12 units 9 hrs/week business & management core Courses I plan to take # 14-601: INI Academic & Professional Development 1 Fall 3 units 3.8 hrs/week core 14-760: Advanced Real World Data Networks Spring 12 units 12.8 hrs/week AoC 14-819: Introduction to Software Reverse-Engineering Spring 12 units 12.7 hrs/week elective 15-605: Operating System Design and Implementation Fall/Spring 15 units 23.8 hrs/week elective 15-619: Cloud Computing Fall/Spring 15 units 24.7 hrs/week elective 15-640: Distributed Systems Fall/Spring 12 units 15.8 hrs/week AoC/system core 18-732: Secure Software Systems Spring 12 units 12.6 hrs/week specific security 18-733: Applied Cryptography Spring 12 units 10.6 hrs/week specific security Expectations # Plan A: Complete Cyber Defense Concentration with Area of Concentration # Stats # core: 75/75 Elective: 60/48 AoC: 36/36 Summer 2025 expected workload: 20 hrs/week units: 6 15-503: Introduction to Computer Systems Fall 2025 expected workload: 43.7 hrs/week units: 39 15-640: Distributed Systems 14-741: Introduction to Information Security 14-817: Cyber Risk Modeling 14-601: INI Academic & Professional Development 1 Spring 2026 expected workload: 45.3 hrs/week units: 39 15-619: Cloud Computing 14-819: Introduction to Software Reverse-Engineering 18-733: Applied Cryptography Fall 2026 expected workload: 54.7 hrs/week units: 48 14-642: Introduction to Embedded Systems 14-740: Fundamentals of Telecommunications Networks 14-735: Secure Coding 14-761: Applied Information Assurance Spring 2027 expected workload: 50.3 hrs/week units: 39 15-605: Operating System Design and Implementation 14-742: Security in Networked Systems 14-760: Advanced Real World Data Networks Plan B: Give up Cyber Defense Concentration and choose Project track # Stats # Core: 75/75 Elective: 48/48 Project: 36/36 Summer 2025 expected workload: 20 hrs/week units: 6 15-503: Introduction to Computer Systems Fall 2025 expected workload: 43.7 hrs/week units: 39 15-640: Distributed Systems 14-741: Introduction to Information Security 14-817: Cyber Risk Modeling 14-601: INI Academic & Professional Development 1 Spring 2026 expected workload: 50 hrs/week units: 39 15-619: Cloud Computing 14-819: Introduction to Software Reverse-Engineering 18-732: Secure Software Systems OR 18-733: Applied Cryptography Fall 2026 expected workload: 47.2 hrs/week units: 39 15-605: Operating System Design and Implementation 14-735: Secure Coding 14-740: Fundamentals of Telecommunications Networks Spring 2027 expected workload: 50 hrs/week units: 36 Capstone Project
title: Fall 2025 Course Registration

content:
Hey there! I'm Patrick. I graduated from CSIE @NCKU in 2024, and currently a master student studying in MSIS @CMU.
I usually play CTFs with friends at B33F 50Î¼P from NCKU and b01lers from Purdue. Cryptography is my favorite. (definitely not just because Iâ€™m only good at math ðŸ˜¢â€¦okay, maybe a little)
Right now Iâ€™m diving into penetration testing, so any tips or advice are greatly appreciated! >:D
title: About Me

content: VISA # Annoying thing, but not for my Bwua ;)
title: CMU preliminary

content: Challenge # from random import randint, randbytes from Crypto.Util.number import isPrime from hashlib import sha256 def proof_of_work(): while True: prefix = randbytes(4) print(f"prefix (hex): {prefix.hex()}") ans = bytes.fromhex(input("ans (hex): ").strip()) if int(sha256(prefix + ans).hexdigest(), 16) & (0xFFFFFF << 232) == 0: break proof_of_work() with open("flag.txt", "r") as f: flag = f.read() f = lambda nbits: randint(13, 37).to_bytes(nbits, 'big') while True: leet_prime = int.from_bytes(randbytes(1 + 3 * 3 - 7), 'big') if isPrime(leet_prime, false_positive_prob=133e-7, randfunc=f): break for _ in range(1337): p = int(input("Prime number: ").strip()) if isPrime(p, false_positive_prob=133e-7, randfunc=f): print(f"The power of leet prime >:D: {pow(leet_prime, p-1**337, p)}") else: print(f"Composite number sucks >:(") if int(input("What is my leet prime: ").strip()) == leet_prime: print(f"Flag for the leet: {flag}")
title: I Made "Leet Prime Challenge" w/ b01lers @Purdue
